awd_titl_txt: Enabling fast and efficient nonaqueous ion (co-)intercalation for high energy density charge storage via systematic interfacial design
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Summary
Understanding the principles of how ions move into lithium-ion battery electrodes is crucial in making reliable and safe batteries that store energy by storing lithium. However, big knowledge gaps remain in the understanding of how these principles apply to other ions such as potassium, sodium, and magnesium; all of these ions are crucial components of exciting next-generation batteries. This project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program at NSF, introduces ultra-thin electrodes, which are composed of a few atom-thick flat layers of carbon, so-called few-layer graphene (FLG), as a platform for identifying problems during the storage of a broad range of ions. Because FLG is so thin, experiments can be performed very quickly. On this project researchers use techniques for seeing through FLG easily, and perform reliable quantum calculations mimicking their behavior. This allows them to swiftly evaluate ion storage performance and to learn fundamental principles impacting battery systems at large. This project aligns to NSF's mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing national prosperity by creating new knowledge on strategic materials for energy storage, such as batteries. This helps the USA to remain at the forefront of science. In order to contribute towards these greater objectives, the PI and co-PI, both identifying with Hispanic communities, offer programs that enrich and make a positive impact on student's learning and scientific life. This is achieved by providing direct educational and research opportunities to undergraduate and K-12 audiences through laboratory experiences and training, and through computational and social media resources. 

Technical Summary
The goal of this project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program at NSF,  is to address challenges in the fundamental understanding of interfacial phenomena faced during ion intercalation on graphitic hosts. While several studies have addressed lithium intercalation kinetics and mechanisms, comparatively fewer have done so on other alkali ions, anions, and multivalent cations. The scope of this project is to use a versatile platform consisting of few-layer graphene (FLG) electrodes which enable high-fidelity, fast, and efficient electrochemistry to address this knowledge gap in a timely manner. FLG electrodes improve experimental throughput with true interfacial selectivity, allowing to swiftly identify and overcome interfacial kinetic barriers. Studies are complemented with insightful compositional analysis, in situ characterization, and robust quantum simulation methods for providing a deep understanding of the intercalation process. This project generates knowledge on the impact of heteroatom surface modification and ion co-intercalation on the kinetics and mechanisms of ion insertion for next generation batteries in an accelerated manner. The identification of PI and co-PI with Hispanic audiences and other underrepresented minority groups helps preparing them to tackle future challenges in energy technologies through demonstrations, laboratory experiences, and social media tools. This project aligns to NSF's mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing national prosperity by providing fundamental understanding of strategic materials for energy storage, creating transformative knowledge for allowing the USA to remain at the forefront of science, and contributing to NSF's 10 Big Ideas by growing convergence research through interdisciplinarity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign Henry Admin Bldg.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF funded research computationally predicted and experimentally demonstrated new surface and bulk contributions to alkali ion insertion in carbon electrodes relevant to the design of batteries beyond Li-ion. The mechanisms and energetics of ion insertion in carbon are not the same for alkali ions such as Li+, Na+, and K+. Understanding and learning how to address these differences is key to developing chemistries that can diversify the portfolio of viable battery technologies, potentially decreasing their cost and increasing the availability of materials and minerals for energy storage. In this project, experimental studies of surface and bulk were enabled by ultrathin, versatile few-layer graphene (FLG) electrodes, in combination with electrochemical and spectroscopic methods, and enhanced using highly stable reference electrodes. These electrodes allowed us to swiftly probe strategies for modifying intercalation activity. For example, computations performed in this project revealed that unlike Li+ and K+, Na+ displays unfavorable energetics for insertion into carbon anodes. This is consistent with experiment and is one of the main reasons why similar materials for Li-ion batteries are not used in Na-ion batteries. However, the same computations also showed that the energetics could be made favorable by modifying the FLG surface with fluorine. In a following experimental study, this was accomplished using a surface reactive approach with XeF2. Experimental methods indeed showed clear electrochemical (i.e., voltametric peaks) and spectroscopic (i.e., changes in Raman spectroscopic bands) signatures for Na+ intercalation. We estimate the formation of the NaC18 compound which has a significantly higher ratio of Na to C compared to those previously reported. Another study highlighted how simultaneous intercalation of Li+ and K+ in FLG could be detected using fast charging methods, enabling understanding of how the rate and charge storage capacity change as a function of electrolyte composition. New electrode designs and synergetic collaboration between experiment (Rodriguez-Lopez, PI) and theory (Mendoza-Cortes, co-PI) led to prompt identification of critical parameters to test our ideas. Our results were disseminated in the literature and through conferences, presentations, and outreach events targeting multiple communities such as for scientists interested in batteries, interfacial electrochemistry, and chemical measurement. The work enabled through this project gets us closer towards understanding battery electrodes that are inexpensive, efficient, fast, and that make better use of natural mineral resources for addressing the grand energy storage challenge of our century.

This project provided learning and participation opportunities to students at all levels of university instruction and reached students from elementary to high-school grades. Both PI and Co-PI involved a diverse group of undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate students in activities directly related to research and the use of cutting-edge materials and their characterization, instruments, and computations. Both PI and Co-PI gave seminars and met with students and other PIs in workshops and conferences to share how new experimental and computational methods can be used for making better battery interfaces. Project-specific educational experiences were created through the "Electrochemical Bootcamp" program which organized three (2020, 2022, and 2023) multi-day experimental electrochemistry experiences for undergraduate, graduate, and postgraduate participants at the University of Illinois. The course includes 6 training modules (basic electrochemical setup, electrocatalysis, simulations, ultramicroelectrodes, batteries and preparative electrochemistry, and scanning electrochemical microscopy), each one divided into 4 round-robin demonstrations and activities in the laboratory or computer. As a result, students are introduced to ~24 different experiments, 6 lectures, and 1 simulation session that enable them to learn the vocabulary and practice of electrochemistry. For novice students the course helps decrease the anxiety to set up and run experiments; for advanced students it challenges their knowledge and fills gaps. During these three editions, we trained more than 80 participants, including a large proportion of students from underrepresented minority groups. The experiences were free of cost. Students from the University of Illinois, in addition from those across the state, the country, and even a few international students attended these events. Public lectures and outreach to social media groups about computational materials also help spark the interest of younger generations. Overall, these activities prepare a well-trained and informed workforce to tackle current challenges in energy storage science.

 


Last Modified: 11/16/2023
Modified by: Joaquin Rodriguez Lopez
